True intelligence relies on "world models" -- causal abstractions that allow an agent to not only predict future states but understand the underlying governing dynamics. While previous "AI Physicist" approaches have successfully recovered such laws, they typically rely on strong, domain-specific priors that effectively "bake in" the physics. Conversely, Vafa et al. recently showed that generic Transformers fail to acquire these world models, achieving high predictive accuracy without capturing the underlying physical laws. We bridge this gap by systematically introducing three minimal inductive biases. We show that ensuring spatial smoothness (by formulating prediction as continuous regression) and stability (by training with noisy contexts to mitigate error accumulation) enables generic Transformers to surpass prior failures and learn a coherent Keplerian world model, successfully fitting ellipses to planetary trajectories. However, true physical insight requires a third bias: temporal locality. By restricting the attention window to the immediate past -- imposing the simple assumption that future states depend only on the local state rather than a complex history -- we force the model to abandon curve-fitting and discover Newtonian force representations. Our results demonstrate that simple architectural choices determine whether an AI becomes a curve-fitter or a physicist, marking a critical step toward automated scientific discovery.

AI.tldr: Generic Transformers can learn physical laws with three minimal inductive biases: spatial smoothness, stability via noisy training, and temporal locality, transforming them from curve-fitters to physicists.
AI.motivation: Previous AI approaches either rely on strong domain-specific physics priors or fail to capture underlying physical laws despite good prediction. The paper aims to bridge this gap by enabling generic AI architectures to discover physical laws rather than just predict outcomes.
AI.method: Introduces three minimal inductive biases: 1) spatial smoothness through continuous regression formulation, 2) stability via training with noisy contexts to mitigate error accumulation, and 3) temporal locality by restricting attention window to immediate past. Tests on Keplerian planetary motion.
AI.result: With first two biases, Transformers learn coherent Keplerian world models and fit ellipses to planetary trajectories. With all three biases (including temporal locality), they discover Newtonian force representations rather than just curve-fitting.
AI.conclusion: Simple architectural choices determine whether AI becomes a curve-fitter or a physicist. Temporal locality bias is crucial for true physical insight, marking a step toward automated scientific discovery with general-purpose AI architectures.

title: Cochain Perspectives on Temporal-Difference Signals for Learning Beyond Markov Dynamics
summary: Non-Markovian dynamics are commonly found in real-world environments due to long-range dependencies, partial observability, and memory effects. The Bellman equation that is the central pillar of Reinforcement learning (RL) becomes only approximately valid under Non-Markovian. Existing work often focus on practical algorithm designs and offer limited theoretical treatment to address key questions, such as what dynamics are indeed capturable by the Bellman framework and how to inspire new algorithm classes with optimal approximations. In this paper, we present a novel topological viewpoint on temporal-difference (TD) based RL. We show that TD errors can be viewed as 1-cochain in the topological space of state transitions, while Markov dynamics are then interpreted as topological integrability. This novel view enables us to obtain a Hodge-type decomposition of TD errors into an integrable component and a topological residual, through a Bellman-de Rham projection. We further propose HodgeFlow Policy Search (HFPS) by fitting a potential network to minimize the non-integrable projection residual in RL, achieving stability/sensitivity guarantees. In numerical evaluations, HFPS is shown to significantly improve RL performance under non-Markovian.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a topological framework for analyzing RL in non-Markovian environments, viewing TD errors as 1-cochains and proposing HodgeFlow Policy Search to handle non-integrable components.
AI.motivation: Real-world RL environments often exhibit non-Markovian dynamics due to long-range dependencies and memory effects, making the standard Bellman equation only approximately valid. Existing work lacks theoretical foundations to understand what dynamics can be captured by Bellman framework and how to design optimal approximations.
AI.method: Proposes a topological viewpoint where TD errors are interpreted as 1-cochains in state transition space, and Markov dynamics as topological integrability. Introduces Hodge-type decomposition of TD errors into integrable and topological residual components via Bellman-de Rham projection. Develops HodgeFlow Policy Search (HFPS) that fits a potential network to minimize non-integrable projection residuals.
AI.result: HFPS achieves stability/sensitivity guarantees and significantly improves RL performance under non-Markovian conditions in numerical evaluations.
AI.conclusion: The topological framework provides theoretical foundations for analyzing RL in non-Markovian environments, enabling decomposition of TD errors and inspiring new algorithm classes with optimal approximations through HodgeFlow Policy Search.

title: Disentanglement by means of action-induced representations
summary: Learning interpretable representations with variational autoencoders (VAEs) is a major goal of representation learning. The main challenge lies in obtaining disentangled representations, where each latent dimension corresponds to a distinct generative factor. This difficulty is fundamentally tied to the inability to perform nonlinear independent component analysis. Here, we introduce the framework of action-induced representations (AIRs) which models representations of physical systems given experiments (or actions) that can be performed on them. We show that, in this framework, we can provably disentangle degrees of freedom w.r.t. their action dependence. We further introduce a variational AIR architecture (VAIR) that can extract AIRs and therefore achieve provable disentanglement where standard VAEs fail. Beyond state representation, VAIR also captures the action dependence of the underlying generative factors, directly linking experiments to the degrees of freedom they influence.

AI.tldr: VAIR framework achieves provable disentanglement by modeling representations based on actions performed on physical systems, overcoming limitations of standard VAEs.
AI.motivation: Standard VAEs struggle with disentangled representations due to the fundamental challenge of nonlinear independent component analysis. The paper aims to learn interpretable representations where each latent dimension corresponds to distinct generative factors.
AI.method: Introduces Action-Induced Representations (AIRs) framework that models representations of physical systems given experiments/actions performed on them. Develops Variational AIR (VAIR) architecture that can extract AIRs and achieve provable disentanglement.
AI.result: The framework can provably disentangle degrees of freedom with respect to their action dependence. VAIR captures both state representation and the action dependence of underlying generative factors, directly linking experiments to the degrees of freedom they influence.
AI.conclusion: AIR framework and VAIR architecture provide a principled approach to achieve provable disentanglement where standard VAEs fail, offering interpretable representations that connect actions to their effects on generative factors.

title: Endogenous Resistance to Activation Steering in Language Models
summary: Large language models can resist task-misaligned activation steering during inference, sometimes recovering mid-generation to produce improved responses even when steering remains active. We term this Endogenous Steering Resistance (ESR). Using sparse autoencoder (SAE) latents to steer model activations, we find that Llama-3.3-70B shows substantial ESR, while smaller models from the Llama-3 and Gemma-2 families exhibit the phenomenon less frequently. We identify 26 SAE latents that activate differentially during off-topic content and are causally linked to ESR in Llama-3.3-70B. Zero-ablating these latents reduces the multi-attempt rate by 25%, providing causal evidence for dedicated internal consistency-checking circuits. We demonstrate that ESR can be deliberately enhanced through both prompting and training: meta-prompts instructing the model to self-monitor increase the multi-attempt rate by 4x for Llama-3.3-70B, and fine-tuning on self-correction examples successfully induces ESR-like behavior in smaller models. These findings have dual implications: ESR could protect against adversarial manipulation but might also interfere with beneficial safety interventions that rely on activation steering. Understanding and controlling these resistance mechanisms is important for developing transparent and controllable AI systems. Code is available at github.com/agencyenterprise/endogenous-steering-resistance.

AI.tldr: LLMs can resist task-misaligned activation steering during inference, recovering mid-generation to produce improved responses even when steering remains active - a phenomenon called Endogenous Steering Resistance (ESR).
AI.motivation: To understand how large language models internally resist adversarial manipulation through activation steering, and to investigate whether this resistance can be enhanced or controlled for developing more transparent and controllable AI systems.
AI.method: Used sparse autoencoder (SAE) latents to steer model activations, identified specific latents linked to ESR, performed zero-ablation experiments, and enhanced ESR through meta-prompting and fine-tuning on self-correction examples.
AI.result: Llama-3.3-70B shows substantial ESR while smaller models exhibit it less frequently. Identified 26 SAE latents causally linked to ESR. Zero-ablating these latents reduces multi-attempt rate by 25%. Meta-prompts increase multi-attempt rate by 4x, and fine-tuning induces ESR-like behavior in smaller models.
AI.conclusion: ESR represents dedicated internal consistency-checking circuits that could protect against adversarial manipulation but might interfere with beneficial safety interventions. Understanding and controlling these resistance mechanisms is crucial for developing transparent and controllable AI systems.

title: Soft Forward-Backward Representations for Zero-shot Reinforcement Learning with General Utilities
summary: Recent advancements in zero-shot reinforcement learning (RL) have facilitated the extraction of diverse behaviors from unlabeled, offline data sources. In particular, forward-backward algorithms (FB) can retrieve a family of policies that can approximately solve any standard RL problem (with additive rewards, linear in the occupancy measure), given sufficient capacity. While retaining zero-shot properties, we tackle the greater problem class of RL with general utilities, in which the objective is an arbitrary differentiable function of the occupancy measure. This setting is strictly more expressive, capturing tasks such as distribution matching or pure exploration, which may not be reduced to additive rewards. We show that this additional complexity can be captured by a novel, maximum entropy (soft) variant of the forward-backward algorithm, which recovers a family of stochastic policies from offline data. When coupled with zero-order search over compact policy embeddings, this algorithm can sidestep iterative optimization schemes, and optimizes general utilities directly at test-time. Across both didactic and high-dimensional experiments, we demonstrate that our method retains favorable properties of FB algorithms, while also extending their range to more general RL problems.

AI.tldr: A novel maximum entropy forward-backward algorithm extends zero-shot RL to general utilities (arbitrary differentiable functions of occupancy measures), enabling direct optimization of diverse tasks like distribution matching without iterative training.
AI.motivation: Existing forward-backward algorithms only handle additive rewards (linear in occupancy measure), but many important RL tasks require general utilities (non-linear functions of occupancy), such as distribution matching or pure exploration. There's a need to extend zero-shot RL capabilities to this broader problem class.
AI.method: Proposes a maximum entropy (soft) variant of forward-backward algorithm that recovers a family of stochastic policies from offline data. Coupled with zero-order search over compact policy embeddings, it can optimize general utilities directly at test-time without iterative optimization schemes.
AI.result: The method retains favorable properties of forward-backward algorithms while extending their range to more general RL problems. Demonstrated effectiveness across both didactic and high-dimensional experiments.
AI.conclusion: The proposed approach successfully extends zero-shot RL to the general utilities setting, enabling direct optimization of diverse tasks beyond additive rewards while maintaining the desirable zero-shot properties of forward-backward algorithms.

title: Learning a Generative Meta-Model of LLM Activations
summary: Existing approaches for analyzing neural network activations, such as PCA and sparse autoencoders, rely on strong structural assumptions. Generative models offer an alternative: they can uncover structure without such assumptions and act as priors that improve intervention fidelity. We explore this direction by training diffusion models on one billion residual stream activations, creating "meta-models" that learn the distribution of a network's internal states. We find that diffusion loss decreases smoothly with compute and reliably predicts downstream utility. In particular, applying the meta-model's learned prior to steering interventions improves fluency, with larger gains as loss decreases. Moreover, the meta-model's neurons increasingly isolate concepts into individual units, with sparse probing scores that scale as loss decreases. These results suggest generative meta-models offer a scalable path toward interpretability without restrictive structural assumptions. Project page: https://generative-latent-prior.github.io.

AI.tldr: Diffusion models trained on neural network activations create "meta-models" that learn internal state distributions, improving interpretability without structural assumptions.
AI.motivation: Existing methods like PCA and sparse autoencoders rely on strong structural assumptions. Generative models offer an alternative that can uncover structure without such assumptions and act as priors to improve intervention fidelity.
AI.method: Train diffusion models on one billion residual stream activations to create "meta-models" that learn the distribution of a network's internal states, then apply the learned prior to steering interventions.
AI.result: Diffusion loss decreases smoothly with compute and reliably predicts downstream utility. Applying the meta-model's learned prior improves fluency in steering interventions, with larger gains as loss decreases. The meta-model's neurons increasingly isolate concepts into individual units with sparse probing scores that scale as loss decreases.
AI.conclusion: Generative meta-models offer a scalable path toward interpretability without restrictive structural assumptions, as demonstrated by improved intervention fidelity and concept isolation.

title: Calibrating Generative AI to Produce Realistic Essays for Data Augmentation
comment: Artificial Intelligence in Measurement and Education Conference (AIME-Con)
summary: Data augmentation can mitigate limited training data in machine-learning automated scoring engines for constructed response items. This study seeks to determine how well three approaches to large language model prompting produce essays that preserve the writing quality of the original essays and produce realistic text for augmenting ASE training datasets. We created simulated versions of student essays, and human raters assigned scores to them and rated the realism of the generated text. The results of the study indicate that the predict next prompting strategy produces the highest level of agreement between human raters regarding simulated essay scores, predict next and sentence strategies best preserve the rated quality of the original essay in the simulated essays, and predict next and 25 examples strategies produce the most realistic text as judged by human raters.

AI.tldr: Three LLM prompting strategies (predict next, sentence, 25 examples) were tested for generating realistic student essays to augment automated scoring training data, with predict next performing best across multiple metrics.
AI.motivation: To address limited training data for automated scoring engines of constructed response items by using LLM-generated essays, while ensuring the generated text preserves original writing quality and appears realistic.
AI.method: Created simulated student essays using three LLM prompting approaches (predict next, sentence, 25 examples), then had human raters score the generated essays and rate their realism compared to original essays.
AI.result: Predict next prompting achieved highest inter-rater agreement on scores, best preserved original essay quality (along with sentence strategy), and produced most realistic text (along with 25 examples strategy).
AI.conclusion: The predict next prompting strategy is most effective for generating realistic, quality-preserving essay data to augment automated scoring engine training datasets.

title: On the Convergence of Multicalibration Gradient Boosting
summary: Multicalibration gradient boosting has recently emerged as a scalable method that empirically produces approximately multicalibrated predictors and has been deployed at web scale. Despite this empirical success, its convergence properties are not well understood. In this paper, we bridge the gap by providing convergence guarantees for multicalibration gradient boosting in regression with squared-error loss. We show that the magnitude of successive prediction updates decays at $O(1/\sqrt{T})$, which implies the same convergence rate bound for the multicalibration error over rounds. Under additional smoothness assumptions on the weak learners, this rate improves to linear convergence. We further analyze adaptive variants, showing local quadratic convergence of the training loss, and we study rescaling schemes that preserve convergence. Experiments on real-world datasets support our theory and clarify the regimes in which the method achieves fast convergence and strong multicalibration.

AI.tldr: Multicalibration gradient boosting converges at O(1/√T) rate for squared-error loss, with linear convergence under smoothness assumptions, and adaptive variants achieve local quadratic convergence.
AI.motivation: Multicalibration gradient boosting has shown empirical success at web scale but lacks theoretical convergence guarantees, creating a gap between practical deployment and theoretical understanding.
AI.method: Analyzes multicalibration gradient boosting in regression with squared-error loss, examining convergence properties, smoothness assumptions on weak learners, adaptive variants, and rescaling schemes.
AI.result: Proves O(1/√T) convergence rate for prediction updates and multicalibration error, linear convergence under smoothness assumptions, local quadratic convergence for adaptive variants, and convergence-preserving rescaling schemes.
AI.conclusion: Theoretical convergence guarantees bridge the empirical-theoretical gap, with experiments validating fast convergence and strong multicalibration in real-world regimes.

title: Robust Online Learning
summary: We study the problem of learning robust classifiers where the classifier will receive a perturbed input. Unlike robust PAC learning studied in prior work, here the clean data and its label are also adversarially chosen. We formulate this setting as an online learning problem and consider both the realizable and agnostic learnability of hypothesis classes. We define a new dimension of classes and show it controls the mistake bounds in the realizable setting and the regret bounds in the agnostic setting. In contrast to the dimension that characterizes learnability in the PAC setting, our dimension is rather simple and resembles the Littlestone dimension. We generalize our dimension to multiclass hypothesis classes and prove similar results in the realizable case. Finally, we study the case where the learner does not know the set of allowed perturbations for each point and only has some prior on them.

AI.tldr: The paper studies robust online learning where both clean data and labels are adversarially chosen, defining a new dimension that controls mistake/regret bounds in realizable/agnostic settings.
AI.motivation: To address robust classification where classifiers receive perturbed inputs, but unlike prior robust PAC learning, both clean data and labels are adversarially chosen, requiring a new online learning formulation.
AI.method: Formulates the problem as online learning, defines a new dimension for hypothesis classes (similar to Littlestone dimension), analyzes realizable and agnostic learnability, extends to multiclass settings, and studies cases with unknown perturbation sets.
AI.result: The new dimension controls mistake bounds in realizable setting and regret bounds in agnostic setting, with simpler structure than PAC dimensions, resembling Littlestone dimension. Results generalize to multiclass hypothesis classes.
AI.conclusion: The paper establishes a new dimension for robust online learning that characterizes learnability when both data and labels are adversarial, providing theoretical foundations for robust classification in adversarial environments.

title: Weisfeiler and Lehman Go Categorical
summary: While lifting map has significantly enhanced the expressivity of graph neural networks, extending this paradigm to hypergraphs remains fragmented. To address this, we introduce the categorical Weisfeiler-Lehman framework, which formalizes lifting as a functorial mapping from an arbitrary data category to the unifying category of graded posets. When applied to hypergraphs, this perspective allows us to systematically derive Hypergraph Isomorphism Networks, a family of neural architectures where the message passing topology is strictly determined by the choice of functor. We introduce two distinct functors from the category of hypergraphs: an incidence functor and a symmetric simplicial complex functor. While the incidence architecture structurally mirrors standard bipartite schemes, our functorial derivation enforces a richer information flow over the resulting poset, capturing complex intersection geometries often missed by existing methods. We theoretically characterize the expressivity of these models, proving that both the incidence-based and symmetric simplicial approaches subsume the expressive power of the standard Hypergraph Weisfeiler-Lehman test. Extensive experiments on real-world benchmarks validate these theoretical findings.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a categorical Weisfeiler-Lehman framework that formalizes lifting as functorial mapping to graded posets, enabling systematic derivation of Hypergraph Isomorphism Networks with message passing topology determined by functor choice.
AI.motivation: While lifting maps have enhanced graph neural network expressivity, extending this paradigm to hypergraphs remains fragmented. The paper aims to provide a unified categorical framework for hypergraph neural architectures.
AI.method: Introduces categorical Weisfeiler-Lehman framework formalizing lifting as functorial mapping from arbitrary data categories to graded posets. Applies to hypergraphs to derive Hypergraph Isomorphism Networks. Introduces two functors: incidence functor and symmetric simplicial complex functor, with message passing topology strictly determined by functor choice.
AI.result: Theoretically characterizes expressivity, proving both incidence-based and symmetric simplicial approaches subsume expressive power of standard Hypergraph Weisfeiler-Lehman test. Extensive experiments on real-world benchmarks validate theoretical findings.
AI.conclusion: The categorical framework provides systematic derivation of hypergraph neural architectures with theoretically guaranteed expressivity, capturing complex intersection geometries often missed by existing methods.

title: Vision Transformer Finetuning Benefits from Non-Smooth Components
summary: The smoothness of the transformer architecture has been extensively studied in the context of generalization, training stability, and adversarial robustness. However, its role in transfer learning remains poorly understood. In this paper, we analyze the ability of vision transformer components to adapt their outputs to changes in inputs, or, in other words, their plasticity. Defined as an average rate of change, it captures the sensitivity to input perturbation; in particular, a high plasticity implies low smoothness. We demonstrate through theoretical analysis and comprehensive experiments that this perspective provides principled guidance in choosing the components to prioritize during adaptation. A key takeaway for practitioners is that the high plasticity of the attention modules and feedforward layers consistently leads to better finetuning performance. Our findings depart from the prevailing assumption that smoothness is desirable, offering a novel perspective on the functional properties of transformers. The code is available at https://github.com/ambroiseodt/vit-plasticity.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes transformer plasticity (sensitivity to input changes) rather than smoothness, finding that high plasticity in attention and feedforward layers leads to better fine-tuning performance.
AI.motivation: While transformer smoothness has been studied for generalization and robustness, its role in transfer learning remains poorly understood. The paper aims to analyze transformer plasticity (rate of change) to provide principled guidance for adaptation.
AI.method: The authors analyze vision transformer plasticity defined as average rate of change, capturing sensitivity to input perturbation. They use theoretical analysis and comprehensive experiments to study how different components adapt to input changes.
AI.result: High plasticity in attention modules and feedforward layers consistently leads to better fine-tuning performance. This challenges the prevailing assumption that smoothness is always desirable.
AI.conclusion: Plasticity provides a novel perspective on transformer functional properties, offering practical guidance for adaptation: prioritize high-plasticity components (attention and feedforward layers) during fine-tuning for better performance.

title: Displacement-Resistant Extensions of DPO with Nonconvex $f$-Divergences
comment: Published as a conference paper at ICLR 2026
summary: DPO and related algorithms align language models by directly optimizing the RLHF objective: find a policy that maximizes the Bradley-Terry reward while staying close to a reference policy through a KL divergence penalty. Previous work showed that this approach could be further generalized: the original problem remains tractable even if the KL divergence is replaced by a family of $f$-divergence with a convex generating function $f$. Our first contribution is to show that convexity of $f$ is not essential. Instead, we identify a more general condition, referred to as DPO-inducing, that precisely characterizes when the RLHF problem remains tractable. Our next contribution is to establish a second condition on $f$ that is necessary to prevent probability displacement, a known empirical phenomenon in which the probabilities of the winner and the loser responses approach zero. We refer to any $f$ that satisfies this condition as displacement-resistant. We finally focus on a specific DPO-inducing and displacement-resistant $f$, leading to our novel SquaredPO loss. Compared to DPO, this new loss offers stronger theoretical guarantees while performing competitively in practice.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a more general theoretical framework for RLHF alignment algorithms, identifies conditions for tractability and prevention of probability displacement, and proposes a new SquaredPO loss with better theoretical guarantees.
AI.motivation: To generalize DPO and related RLHF alignment algorithms beyond convex f-divergences, identify precise conditions for tractability, and address the empirical problem of probability displacement where response probabilities approach zero.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis identifying two key conditions: 1) DPO-inducing condition for tractability of RLHF problem with f-divergence, and 2) displacement-resistant condition to prevent probability collapse. Proposes SquaredPO loss based on specific f satisfying both conditions.
AI.result: Shows convexity of f is not essential for tractability, identifies precise DPO-inducing condition, establishes displacement-resistant condition, and demonstrates SquaredPO loss performs competitively with DPO while offering stronger theoretical guarantees.
AI.conclusion: The paper provides a more general theoretical foundation for RLHF alignment algorithms, addresses the probability displacement problem, and introduces SquaredPO as a theoretically sound alternative to DPO with practical competitiveness.

title: Rare Event Analysis of Large Language Models
summary: Being probabilistic models, during inference large language models (LLMs) display rare events: behaviour that is far from typical but highly significant. By definition all rare events are hard to see, but the enormous scale of LLM usage means that events completely unobserved during development are likely to become prominent in deployment. Here we present an end-to-end framework for the systematic analysis of rare events in LLMs. We provide a practical implementation spanning theory, efficient generation strategies, probability estimation and error analysis, which we illustrate with concrete examples. We outline extensions and applications to other models and contexts, highlighting the generality of the concepts and techniques presented here.

AI.tldr: Framework for systematic analysis of rare events in LLMs, covering theory, generation strategies, probability estimation, and error analysis.
AI.motivation: LLMs exhibit rare but significant behaviors that are hard to observe during development but become prominent at deployment scale. Need systematic approach to analyze these probabilistic anomalies.
AI.method: End-to-end framework with practical implementation including theoretical foundations, efficient generation strategies for rare events, probability estimation techniques, and error analysis methods.
AI.result: Provides concrete examples illustrating the framework's application and demonstrates its effectiveness for analyzing rare events in LLMs.
AI.conclusion: The framework is generalizable to other models and contexts, offering systematic tools for rare event analysis in probabilistic AI systems.

title: FlowDA: Accurate, Low-Latency Weather Data Assimilation via Flow Matching
summary: Data assimilation (DA) is a fundamental component of modern weather prediction, yet it remains a major computational bottleneck in machine learning (ML)-based forecasting pipelines due to reliance on traditional variational methods. Recent generative ML-based DA methods offer a promising alternative but typically require many sampling steps and suffer from error accumulation under long-horizon auto-regressive rollouts with cycling assimilation. We propose FlowDA, a low-latency weather-scale generative DA framework based on flow matching. FlowDA conditions on observations through a SetConv-based embedding and fine-tunes the Aurora foundation model to deliver accurate, efficient, and robust analyses. Experiments across observation rates decreasing from $3.9\%$ to $0.1\%$ demonstrate superior performance of FlowDA over strong baselines with similar tunable-parameter size. FlowDA further shows robustness to observational noise and stable performance in long-horizon auto-regressive cycling DA. Overall, FlowDA points to an efficient and scalable direction for data-driven DA.

AI.tldr: FlowDA is a flow matching-based generative data assimilation framework that provides low-latency weather analysis by fine-tuning the Aurora foundation model, outperforming baselines across sparse observation rates and showing robustness in long-horizon cycling assimilation.
AI.motivation: Traditional variational data assimilation methods are computationally expensive bottlenecks in ML-based weather forecasting pipelines. Existing generative ML-based DA methods suffer from slow sampling and error accumulation in long-horizon auto-regressive cycling assimilation.
AI.method: FlowDA uses flow matching for generative data assimilation, conditions on observations through SetConv-based embeddings, and fine-tunes the Aurora foundation model to achieve efficient and accurate weather analysis.
AI.result: FlowDA demonstrates superior performance over strong baselines across observation rates from 3.9% to 0.1%, shows robustness to observational noise, and maintains stable performance in long-horizon auto-regressive cycling DA.
AI.conclusion: FlowDA provides an efficient and scalable direction for data-driven data assimilation, offering accurate, low-latency weather analysis that addresses computational bottlenecks in ML-based forecasting pipelines.

title: Calibrating Tabular Anomaly Detection via Optimal Transport
summary: Tabular anomaly detection (TAD) remains challenging due to the heterogeneity of tabular data: features lack natural relationships, vary widely in distribution and scale, and exhibit diverse types. Consequently, each TAD method makes implicit assumptions about anomaly patterns that work well on some datasets but fail on others, and no method consistently outperforms across diverse scenarios. We present CTAD (Calibrating Tabular Anomaly Detection), a model-agnostic post-processing framework that enhances any existing TAD detector through sample-specific calibration. Our approach characterizes normal data via two complementary distributions, i.e., an empirical distribution from random sampling and a structural distribution from K-means centroids, and measures how adding a test sample disrupts their compatibility using Optimal Transport (OT) distance. Normal samples maintain low disruption while anomalies cause high disruption, providing a calibration signal to amplify detection. We prove that OT distance has a lower bound proportional to the test sample's distance from centroids, and establish that anomalies systematically receive higher calibration scores than normals in expectation, explaining why the method generalizes across datasets. Extensive experiments on 34 diverse tabular datasets with 7 representative detectors spanning all major TAD categories (density estimation, classification, reconstruction, and isolation-based methods) demonstrate that CTAD consistently improves performance with statistical significance. Remarkably, CTAD enhances even state-of-the-art deep learning methods and shows robust performance across diverse hyperparameter settings, requiring no additional tuning for practical deployment.

AI.tldr: CTAD is a model-agnostic post-processing framework that calibrates any tabular anomaly detector using Optimal Transport to measure how test samples disrupt normal data distributions, consistently improving detection performance across diverse datasets.
AI.motivation: Tabular anomaly detection is challenging due to data heterogeneity - features lack natural relationships, vary in distribution/scale, and have diverse types. Existing methods make implicit assumptions that work well on some datasets but fail on others, with no method consistently outperforming across diverse scenarios.
AI.method: CTAD characterizes normal data via two complementary distributions: empirical distribution from random sampling and structural distribution from K-means centroids. It measures how adding a test sample disrupts their compatibility using Optimal Transport distance. Normal samples maintain low disruption while anomalies cause high disruption, providing calibration signals to amplify detection.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on 34 diverse tabular datasets with 7 representative detectors spanning all major TAD categories show CTAD consistently improves performance with statistical significance. It enhances even state-of-the-art deep learning methods and shows robust performance across diverse hyperparameter settings.
AI.conclusion: CTAD provides a practical, model-agnostic post-processing framework that generalizes across datasets by systematically giving anomalies higher calibration scores than normals in expectation, requiring no additional tuning for deployment.

title: Learning Deep Hybrid Models with Sharpness-Aware Minimization
summary: Hybrid modeling, the combination of machine learning models and scientific mathematical models, enables flexible and robust data-driven prediction with partial interpretability. However, effectively the scientific models may be ignored in prediction due to the flexibility of the machine learning model, making the idea of hybrid modeling pointless. Typically some regularization is applied to hybrid model learning to avoid such a failure case, but the formulation of the regularizer strongly depends on model architectures and domain knowledge. In this paper, we propose to focus on the flatness of loss minima in learning hybrid models, aiming to make the model as simple as possible. We employ the idea of sharpness-aware minimization and adapt it to the hybrid modeling setting. Numerical experiments show that the SAM-based method works well across different choices of models and datasets.

AI.tldr: Proposes using sharpness-aware minimization (SAM) to improve hybrid modeling by focusing on flat loss minima, preventing ML models from ignoring scientific components.
AI.motivation: Hybrid models combining ML and scientific models can fail when ML components dominate and ignore scientific models, making hybrid modeling pointless. Existing regularization approaches are architecture-specific and require domain knowledge.
AI.method: Adapts sharpness-aware minimization (SAM) to hybrid modeling to find flat minima in the loss landscape, making models simpler and more robust to prevent ML from ignoring scientific components.
AI.result: Numerical experiments show the SAM-based method works well across different model architectures and datasets, demonstrating broad applicability.
AI.conclusion: Focusing on flatness of loss minima via SAM provides an effective, architecture-agnostic approach to ensure scientific models are properly utilized in hybrid modeling.

title: Improved Sampling Schedules for Discrete Diffusion Models
summary: Discrete diffusion models have emerged as a powerful paradigm for generative modeling on sequence data; however, the information-theoretic principles governing their reverse processes remain significantly less understood than those of their continuous counterparts. In this work, we bridge this gap by analyzing the reverse process dynamics through the lens of thermodynamic entropy production. We propose the entropy production rate as a rigorous proxy for quantifying information generation, deriving as a byproduct a bound on the Wasserstein distance between intermediate states and the data distribution. Leveraging these insights, we introduce two novel sampling schedules that are uniformly spaced with respect to their corresponding physics-inspired metrics: the Entropic Discrete Schedule (EDS), which is defined by maintaining a constant rate of information gain, and the Wasserstein Discrete Schedule (WDS), which is defined by taking equal steps in terms of the Wasserstein distance. We empirically demonstrate that our proposed schedules significantly outperform state-of-the-art strategies across diverse application domains, including synthetic data, music notation, vision and language modeling, consistently achieving superior performance at a lower computational budget.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes discrete diffusion models through thermodynamic entropy production, proposes entropy production rate as a measure of information generation, and introduces two novel sampling schedules (EDS and WDS) that outperform existing methods across multiple domains.
AI.motivation: Discrete diffusion models are powerful for sequence data generation, but their reverse processes lack the theoretical understanding that continuous diffusion models have. The authors aim to bridge this gap by analyzing reverse process dynamics through thermodynamic entropy production principles.
AI.method: The authors analyze discrete diffusion reverse processes using thermodynamic entropy production theory. They propose entropy production rate as a proxy for quantifying information generation and derive a bound on Wasserstein distance between intermediate states and data distribution. Based on these insights, they introduce two novel sampling schedules: Entropic Discrete Schedule (EDS) which maintains constant information gain rate, and Wasserstein Discrete Schedule (WDS) which takes equal steps in Wasserstein distance.
AI.result: The proposed EDS and WDS schedules significantly outperform state-of-the-art sampling strategies across diverse domains including synthetic data, music notation, vision, and language modeling. They consistently achieve superior performance while requiring lower computational budget.
AI.conclusion: Thermodynamic entropy production provides a rigorous framework for understanding discrete diffusion models. The proposed physics-inspired sampling schedules (EDS and WDS) offer practical improvements in efficiency and performance, demonstrating the value of theoretical analysis for guiding practical algorithm design in discrete diffusion models.

title: Designing a Robust, Bounded, and Smooth Loss Function for Improved Supervised Learning
summary: The loss function is crucial to machine learning, especially in supervised learning frameworks. It is a fundamental component that controls the behavior and general efficacy of learning algorithms. However, despite their widespread use, traditional loss functions have significant drawbacks when dealing with high-dimensional and outlier-sensitive datasets, which frequently results in reduced performance and slower convergence during training. In this work, we develop a robust, bounded, and smooth (RoBoS-NN) loss function to resolve the aforementioned hindrances. The generalization ability of the loss function has also been theoretically analyzed to rigorously justify its robustness. Moreover, we implement RoboS-NN loss in the framework of a neural network (NN) to forecast time series and present a new robust algorithm named $\mathcal{L}_{\text{RoBoS}}$-NN. To assess the potential of $\mathcal{L}_{\text{RoBoS}}$-NN, we conduct experiments on multiple real-world datasets. In addition, we infuse outliers into data sets to evaluate the performance of $\mathcal{L}_{\text{RoBoS}}$-NN in more challenging scenarios. Numerical results show that $\mathcal{L}_{\text{RoBoS}}$-NN outperforms the other benchmark models in terms of accuracy measures.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces RoBoS-NN, a robust, bounded, and smooth loss function for neural networks that addresses issues with traditional loss functions in high-dimensional and outlier-sensitive datasets, leading to improved time series forecasting performance.
AI.motivation: Traditional loss functions have significant drawbacks when dealing with high-dimensional and outlier-sensitive datasets, resulting in reduced performance and slower convergence during training. There's a need for more robust loss functions that can handle these challenges effectively.
AI.method: Developed a robust, bounded, and smooth (RoBoS-NN) loss function with theoretical analysis of its generalization ability. Implemented this loss in a neural network framework for time series forecasting, creating the L_RoBoS-NN algorithm. Tested on multiple real-world datasets with and without injected outliers.
AI.result: Numerical results show that L_RoBoS-NN outperforms other benchmark models in terms of accuracy measures, particularly in challenging scenarios with outliers.
AI.conclusion: The RoBoS-NN loss function successfully addresses limitations of traditional loss functions, providing improved robustness and performance for neural networks in time series forecasting, especially in the presence of outliers and high-dimensional data.

title: T-STAR: A Context-Aware Transformer Framework for Short-Term Probabilistic Demand Forecasting in Dock-Based Shared Micro-Mobility
comment: This work has been submitted to Transportation Research Part C
summary: Reliable short-term demand forecasting is essential for managing shared micro-mobility services and ensuring responsive, user-centered operations. This study introduces T-STAR (Two-stage Spatial and Temporal Adaptive contextual Representation), a novel transformer-based probabilistic framework designed to forecast station-level bike-sharing demand at a 15-minute resolution. T-STAR addresses key challenges in high-resolution forecasting by disentangling consistent demand patterns from short-term fluctuations through a hierarchical two-stage structure. The first stage captures coarse-grained hourly demand patterns, while the second stage improves prediction accuracy by incorporating high-frequency, localized inputs, including recent fluctuations and real-time demand variations in connected metro services, to account for temporal shifts in short-term demand. Time series transformer models are employed in both stages to generate probabilistic predictions. Extensive experiments using Washington D.C.'s Capital Bikeshare data demonstrate that T-STAR outperforms existing methods in both deterministic and probabilistic accuracy. The model exhibits strong spatial and temporal robustness across stations and time periods. A zero-shot forecasting experiment further highlights T-STAR's ability to transfer to previously unseen service areas without retraining. These results underscore the framework's potential to deliver granular, reliable, and uncertainty-aware short-term demand forecasts, which enable seamless integration to support multimodal trip planning for travelers and enhance real-time operations in shared micro-mobility services.

AI.tldr: T-STAR is a two-stage transformer framework for 15-minute bike-sharing demand forecasting that separates consistent patterns from short-term fluctuations, incorporating metro service data for improved accuracy.
AI.motivation: Reliable short-term demand forecasting is crucial for managing shared micro-mobility services and enabling responsive, user-centered operations. High-resolution forecasting faces challenges in disentangling consistent patterns from short-term fluctuations.
AI.method: T-STAR uses a hierarchical two-stage transformer structure: first stage captures coarse-grained hourly patterns, second stage incorporates high-frequency localized inputs (recent fluctuations, real-time metro demand) to account for temporal shifts. Both stages use time series transformers for probabilistic predictions.
AI.result: Extensive experiments with Washington D.C. Capital Bikeshare data show T-STAR outperforms existing methods in deterministic and probabilistic accuracy, demonstrates strong spatial/temporal robustness, and successfully transfers to unseen service areas in zero-shot forecasting without retraining.
AI.conclusion: T-STAR delivers granular, reliable, uncertainty-aware short-term demand forecasts that support multimodal trip planning and enhance real-time operations in shared micro-mobility services through seamless integration.

title: Decoupling Variance and Scale-Invariant Updates in Adaptive Gradient Descent for Unified Vector and Matrix Optimization
summary: Adaptive methods like Adam have become the $\textit{de facto}$ standard for large-scale vector and Euclidean optimization due to their coordinate-wise adaptation with a second-order nature. More recently, matrix-based spectral optimizers like Muon (Jordan et al., 2024b) show the power of treating weight matrices as matrices rather than long vectors. Linking these is hard because many natural generalizations are not feasible to implement, and we also cannot simply move the Adam adaptation to the matrix spectrum. To address this, we reformulate the AdaGrad update and decompose it into a variance adaptation term and a scale-invariant term. This decoupling produces $\textbf{DeVA}$ ($\textbf{De}$coupled $\textbf{V}$ariance $\textbf{A}$daptation), a framework that bridges between vector-based variance adaptation and matrix spectral optimization, enabling a seamless transition from Adam to adaptive spectral descent. Extensive experiments across language modeling and image classification demonstrate that DeVA consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods such as Muon and SOAP (Vyas et al., 2024), reducing token usage by around 6.6\%. Theoretically, we show that the variance adaptation term effectively improves the blockwise smoothness, facilitating faster convergence. Our implementation is available at https://github.com/Tsedao/Decoupled-Variance-Adaptation

AI.tldr: DeVA is a new optimization framework that bridges vector-based variance adaptation (like Adam) with matrix spectral optimization (like Muon) by decoupling AdaGrad into variance adaptation and scale-invariant terms, enabling seamless transition between approaches.
AI.motivation: Current optimization landscape has two successful but disconnected approaches: vector-based adaptive methods (Adam) that use coordinate-wise adaptation, and matrix-based spectral optimizers (Muon) that treat weight matrices as matrices. Bridging these is challenging because natural generalizations are infeasible to implement, and Adam's adaptation cannot be directly moved to matrix spectrum.
AI.method: Reformulate AdaGrad update and decompose it into two components: a variance adaptation term and a scale-invariant term. This decoupling produces DeVA framework, which enables seamless transition from Adam to adaptive spectral descent by bridging vector-based variance adaptation with matrix spectral optimization.
AI.result: DeVA consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods like Muon and SOAP across language modeling and image classification tasks, reducing token usage by around 6.6%. Theoretically, the variance adaptation term improves blockwise smoothness, facilitating faster convergence.
AI.conclusion: DeVA successfully bridges the gap between vector-based adaptive optimization and matrix spectral optimization, providing a unified framework that leverages the strengths of both approaches while achieving superior practical performance and theoretical convergence properties.

title: A Cycle-Consistent Graph Surrogate for Full-Cycle Left Ventricular Myocardial Biomechanics
summary: Image-based patient-specific simulation of left ventricular (LV) mechanics is valuable for understanding cardiac function and supporting clinical intervention planning, but conventional finite-element analysis (FEA) is computationally intensive. Current graph-based surrogates do not have full-cycle prediction capabilities, and physics-informed neural networks often struggle to converge on complex cardiac geometries. We present CardioGraphFENet (CGFENet), a unified graph-based surrogate for rapid full-cycle estimation of LV myocardial biomechanics, supervised by a large FEA simulation dataset. The proposed model integrates (i) a global--local graph encoder to capture mesh features with weak-form-inspired global coupling, (ii) a gated recurrent unit-based temporal encoder conditioned on the target volume-time signal to model cycle-coherent dynamics, and (iii) a cycle-consistent bidirectional formulation for both loading and inverse unloading within a single framework. These strategies enable high fidelity with respect to traditional FEA ground truths and produce physiologically plausible pressure-volume loops that match FEA results when coupled with a lumped-parameter model. In particular, the cycle-consistency strategy enables a significant reduction in FEA supervision with only minimal loss in accuracy.

AI.tldr: CGFENet: A graph-based surrogate model for rapid full-cycle estimation of left ventricular biomechanics, supervised by FEA simulation data, with cycle-consistent bidirectional formulation and global-local graph encoding.
AI.motivation: Conventional FEA for LV mechanics is computationally intensive. Existing graph-based surrogates lack full-cycle prediction capabilities, and physics-informed neural networks struggle with complex cardiac geometries.
AI.method: Integrates: (1) global-local graph encoder for mesh features with weak-form-inspired global coupling, (2) GRU-based temporal encoder conditioned on volume-time signals for cycle-coherent dynamics, (3) cycle-consistent bidirectional formulation for loading/unloading in single framework.
AI.result: Achieves high fidelity to FEA ground truths, produces physiologically plausible pressure-volume loops matching FEA results when coupled with lumped-parameter model. Cycle-consistency enables significant reduction in FEA supervision with minimal accuracy loss.
AI.conclusion: CGFENet provides a unified graph-based surrogate for rapid full-cycle LV biomechanics estimation, overcoming limitations of conventional FEA and existing surrogates while maintaining accuracy with reduced supervision.

title: Sample Complexity of Causal Identification with Temporal Heterogeneity
summary: Recovering a unique causal graph from observational data is an ill-posed problem because multiple generating mechanisms can lead to the same observational distribution. This problem becomes solvable only by exploiting specific structural or distributional assumptions. While recent work has separately utilized time-series dynamics or multi-environment heterogeneity to constrain this problem, we integrate both as complementary sources of heterogeneity. This integration yields unified necessary identifiability conditions and enables a rigorous analysis of the statistical limits of recovery under thin versus heavy-tailed noise. In particular, temporal structure is shown to effectively substitute for missing environmental diversity, possibly achieving identifiability even under insufficient heterogeneity. Extending this analysis to heavy-tailed (Student's t) distributions, we demonstrate that while geometric identifiability conditions remain invariant, the sample complexity diverges significantly from the Gaussian baseline. Explicit information-theoretic bounds quantify this cost of robustness, establishing the fundamental limits of covariance-based causal graph recovery methods in realistic non-stationary systems. This work shifts the focus from whether causal structure is identifiable to whether it is statistically recoverable in practice.

AI.tldr: This paper integrates time-series dynamics and multi-environment heterogeneity to establish unified identifiability conditions for causal graph recovery, analyzing statistical limits under different noise distributions and quantifying the cost of robustness.
AI.motivation: Causal graph recovery from observational data is ill-posed due to multiple generating mechanisms producing the same distribution. The paper aims to address this by combining time-series dynamics and multi-environment heterogeneity as complementary sources of information to constrain the problem.
AI.method: The paper integrates time-series dynamics and multi-environment heterogeneity to derive unified necessary identifiability conditions. It analyzes statistical recovery limits under both thin-tailed (Gaussian) and heavy-tailed (Student's t) noise distributions, establishing information-theoretic bounds for covariance-based causal graph recovery methods.
AI.result: Temporal structure can substitute for missing environmental diversity, potentially achieving identifiability even with insufficient heterogeneity. While geometric identifiability conditions remain invariant under heavy-tailed distributions, sample complexity diverges significantly from Gaussian baselines. Explicit information-theoretic bounds quantify the cost of robustness.
AI.conclusion: The work shifts focus from whether causal structure is identifiable to whether it is statistically recoverable in practice, establishing fundamental limits for causal graph recovery in realistic non-stationary systems and quantifying the trade-offs between different sources of heterogeneity.

title: Parameter-free Dynamic Regret: Time-varying Movement Costs, Delayed Feedback, and Memory
summary: In this paper, we study dynamic regret in unconstrained online convex optimization (OCO) with movement costs. Specifically, we generalize the standard setting by allowing the movement cost coefficients $λ_t$ to vary arbitrarily over time. Our main contribution is a novel algorithm that establishes the first comparator-adaptive dynamic regret bound for this setting, guaranteeing $\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}(\sqrt{(1+P_T)(T+\sum_t λ_t)})$ regret, where $P_T$ is the path length of the comparator sequence over $T$ rounds. This recovers the optimal guarantees for both static and dynamic regret in standard OCO as a special case where $λ_t=0$ for all rounds. To demonstrate the versatility of our results, we consider two applications: OCO with delayed feedback and OCO with time-varying memory. We show that both problems can be translated into time-varying movement costs, establishing a novel reduction specifically for the delayed feedback setting that is of independent interest. A crucial observation is that the first-order dependence on movement costs in our regret bound plays a key role in enabling optimal comparator-adaptive dynamic regret guarantees in both settings.

AI.tldr: Novel algorithm for unconstrained online convex optimization with time-varying movement costs achieves comparator-adaptive dynamic regret bound, generalizing standard OCO results and enabling optimal guarantees for delayed feedback and time-varying memory settings.
AI.motivation: The paper addresses the limitation of standard OCO with movement costs where movement cost coefficients are typically fixed. By allowing these coefficients to vary arbitrarily over time, the authors create a more general framework that can model real-world scenarios like delayed feedback and time-varying memory constraints.
AI.method: The authors develop a novel algorithm for unconstrained OCO with time-varying movement costs. They establish a reduction framework that translates problems with delayed feedback and time-varying memory into the time-varying movement cost setting. A key technical contribution is a novel reduction specifically for the delayed feedback setting.
AI.result: The algorithm achieves $\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}(\sqrt{(1+P_T)(T+\sum_t λ_t)})$ comparator-adaptive dynamic regret bound, where $P_T$ is the path length of the comparator sequence. This recovers optimal guarantees for both static and dynamic regret in standard OCO when $λ_t=0$. The results enable optimal comparator-adaptive dynamic regret guarantees for OCO with delayed feedback and OCO with time-varying memory.
AI.conclusion: The paper successfully generalizes OCO with movement costs to allow time-varying coefficients, establishing the first comparator-adaptive dynamic regret bound for this setting. The framework's versatility is demonstrated through applications to delayed feedback and time-varying memory problems, with the first-order dependence on movement costs being crucial for achieving optimal guarantees in these settings.

title: A first realization of reinforcement learning-based closed-loop EEG-TMS
summary: Background: Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) is a powerful tool to investigate neurophysiology of the human brain and treat brain disorders. Traditionally, therapeutic TMS has been applied in a one-size-fits-all approach, disregarding inter- and intra-individual differences. Brain state-dependent EEG-TMS, such as coupling TMS with a pre-specified phase of the sensorimotor mu-rhythm, enables the induction of differential neuroplastic effects depending on the targeted phase. But this approach is still user-dependent as it requires defining an a-priori target phase. Objectives: To present a first realization of a machine-learning-based, closed-loop real-time EEG-TMS setup to identify user-independently the individual mu-rhythm phase associated with high- vs. low-corticospinal excitability states. Methods: We applied EEG-TMS to 25 participants targeting the supplementary motor area-primary motor cortex network and used a reinforcement learning algorithm to identify the mu-rhythm phase associated with high- vs. low corticospinal excitability. We employed linear mixed effects models and Bayesian analysis to determine effects of reinforced learning on corticospinal excitability indexed by motor evoked potential amplitude, and functional connectivity indexed by the imaginary part of resting-state EEG coherence. Results: Reinforcement learning effectively identified the mu-rhythm phase associated with high- vs. low-excitability states, and their repetitive stimulation resulted in long-term increases vs. decreases in functional connectivity in the stimulated sensorimotor network. Conclusions: We demonstrated for the first time the feasibility of closed-loop EEG-TMS in humans, a critical step towards individualized treatment of brain disorders.

AI.tldr: First demonstration of a machine-learning-based closed-loop EEG-TMS system that automatically identifies individual mu-rhythm phases associated with high vs low corticospinal excitability, enabling personalized brain stimulation.
AI.motivation: Traditional TMS therapy uses a one-size-fits-all approach that ignores individual differences. Current brain state-dependent EEG-TMS requires manual definition of target phases, making it user-dependent. There's a need for automated, individualized approaches.
AI.method: Applied EEG-TMS to 25 participants targeting the SMA-M1 network. Used reinforcement learning algorithm to identify mu-rhythm phases associated with high vs low corticospinal excitability. Analyzed effects using linear mixed effects models and Bayesian analysis.
AI.result: Reinforcement learning successfully identified individual mu-rhythm phases linked to excitability states. Stimulation of these phases produced long-term increases vs decreases in functional connectivity within the sensorimotor network.
AI.conclusion: First demonstration of closed-loop EEG-TMS feasibility in humans, representing a critical advancement towards individualized treatment of brain disorders through automated, personalized brain stimulation.

title: Revisiting the Generic Transformer: Deconstructing a Strong Baseline for Time Series Foundation Models
summary: The recent surge in Time Series Foundation Models has rapidly advanced the field, yet the heterogeneous training setups across studies make it difficult to attribute improvements to architectural innovations versus data engineering. In this work, we investigate the potential of a standard patch Transformer, demonstrating that this generic architecture achieves state-of-the-art zero-shot forecasting performance using a straightforward training protocol. We conduct a comprehensive ablation study that covers model scaling, data composition, and training techniques to isolate the essential ingredients for high performance. Our findings identify the key drivers of performance, while confirming that the generic architecture itself demonstrates excellent scalability. By strictly controlling these variables, we provide comprehensive empirical results on model scaling across multiple dimensions. We release our open-source model and detailed findings to establish a transparent, reproducible baseline for future research.

AI.tldr: A standard patch Transformer achieves state-of-the-art zero-shot forecasting performance with simple training, challenging the need for complex architectures in time series foundation models.
AI.motivation: The heterogeneous training setups in Time Series Foundation Models make it difficult to distinguish whether performance improvements come from architectural innovations or data engineering. Researchers want to establish clear baselines to understand what truly drives performance.
AI.method: The study uses a standard patch Transformer architecture with a straightforward training protocol. It conducts comprehensive ablation studies covering model scaling, data composition, and training techniques to isolate essential performance drivers.
AI.result: The generic patch Transformer achieves state-of-the-art zero-shot forecasting performance. The research identifies key performance drivers and confirms the architecture's excellent scalability. Comprehensive empirical results on model scaling across multiple dimensions are provided.
AI.conclusion: A standard patch Transformer with proper training can achieve top performance, challenging assumptions about needing complex architectures. The work establishes a transparent, reproducible baseline for future research by releasing open-source models and detailed findings.

title: Robustness Beyond Known Groups with Low-rank Adaptation
summary: Deep learning models trained to optimize average accuracy often exhibit systematic failures on particular subpopulations. In real world settings, the subpopulations most affected by such disparities are frequently unlabeled or unknown, thereby motivating the development of methods that are performant on sensitive subgroups without being pre-specified. However, existing group-robust methods typically assume prior knowledge of relevant subgroups, using group annotations for training or model selection. We propose Low-rank Error Informed Adaptation (LEIA), a simple two-stage method that improves group robustness by identifying a low-dimensional subspace in the representation space where model errors concentrate. LEIA restricts adaptation to this error-informed subspace via a low-rank adjustment to the classifier logits, directly targeting latent failure modes without modifying the backbone or requiring group labels. Using five real-world datasets, we analyze group robustness under three settings: (1) truly no knowledge of subgroup relevance, (2) partial knowledge of subgroup relevance, and (3) full knowledge of subgroup relevance. Across all settings, LEIA consistently improves worst-group performance while remaining fast, parameter-efficient, and robust to hyperparameter choice.

AI.tldr: LEIA improves model robustness on unknown subgroups by identifying error-concentrated subspaces and applying low-rank adjustments, outperforming existing methods without requiring group labels.
AI.motivation: Deep learning models often fail on specific subpopulations, but these subgroups are frequently unlabeled or unknown in real-world settings. Existing group-robust methods require prior knowledge of relevant subgroups, which limits their practical applicability.
AI.method: LEIA is a two-stage method that first identifies a low-dimensional subspace in the representation space where model errors concentrate. Then it restricts adaptation to this error-informed subspace via a low-rank adjustment to the classifier logits, directly targeting latent failure modes without modifying the backbone or requiring group labels.
AI.result: Across five real-world datasets and three settings (no knowledge, partial knowledge, and full knowledge of subgroup relevance), LEIA consistently improves worst-group performance while remaining fast, parameter-efficient, and robust to hyperparameter choice.
AI.conclusion: LEIA provides an effective approach for improving group robustness without requiring prior knowledge of relevant subgroups, making it practical for real-world applications where sensitive subgroups are often unlabeled or unknown.

title: Continuous-time reinforcement learning: ellipticity enables model-free value function approximation
summary:
We study off-policy reinforcement learning for controlling continuous-time Markov diffusion processes with discrete-time observations and actions. We consider model-free algorithms with function approximation that learn value and advantage functions directly from data, without unrealistic structural assumptions on the dynamics.
  Leveraging the ellipticity of the diffusions, we establish a new class of Hilbert-space positive definiteness and boundedness properties for the Bellman operators. Based on these properties, we propose the Sobolev-prox fitted $q$-learning algorithm, which learns value and advantage functions by iteratively solving least-squares regression problems. We derive oracle inequalities for the estimation error, governed by (i) the best approximation error of the function classes, (ii) their localized complexity, (iii) exponentially decaying optimization error, and (iv) numerical discretization error. These results identify ellipticity as a key structural property that renders reinforcement learning with function approximation for Markov diffusions no harder than supervised learning.

AI.tldr: Off-policy RL for continuous-time Markov diffusion processes with discrete-time observations/actions, using model-free algorithms with function approximation. Establishes Hilbert-space properties for Bellman operators via ellipticity, proposes Sobolev-prox fitted q-learning, and shows RL is no harder than supervised learning.
AI.motivation: To develop reinforcement learning methods for continuous-time Markov diffusion processes that can handle discrete-time observations and actions without unrealistic structural assumptions on the dynamics. The goal is to make RL for such processes tractable and comparable in difficulty to supervised learning.
AI.method: Proposes Sobolev-prox fitted q-learning algorithm that learns value and advantage functions by iteratively solving least-squares regression problems. Leverages ellipticity of diffusions to establish Hilbert-space positive definiteness and boundedness properties for Bellman operators, enabling function approximation.
AI.result: Derives oracle inequalities for estimation error governed by: (1) best approximation error of function classes, (2) their localized complexity, (3) exponentially decaying optimization error, and (4) numerical discretization error. Shows ellipticity makes RL with function approximation for Markov diffusions no harder than supervised learning.
AI.conclusion: Ellipticity of Markov diffusion processes is a key structural property that enables efficient reinforcement learning with function approximation. The proposed Sobolev-prox fitted q-learning algorithm provides theoretical guarantees comparable to supervised learning, making RL for continuous-time diffusions tractable.

title: When RL Meets Adaptive Speculative Training: A Unified Training-Serving System
summary:
Speculative decoding can significantly accelerate LLM serving, yet most deployments today disentangle speculator training from serving, treating speculator training as a standalone offline modeling problem. We show that this decoupled formulation introduces substantial deployment and adaptation lag: (1) high time-to-serve, since a speculator must be trained offline for a considerable period before deployment; (2) delayed utility feedback, since the true end-to-end decoding speedup is only known after training and cannot be inferred reliably from acceptance rate alone due to model-architecture and system-level overheads; and (3) domain-drift degradation, as the target model is repurposed to new domains and the speculator becomes stale and less effective.
  To address these issues, we present Aurora, a unified training-serving system that closes the loop by continuously learning a speculator directly from live inference traces. Aurora reframes online speculator learning as an asynchronous reinforcement-learning problem: accepted tokens provide positive feedback, while rejected speculator proposals provide implicit negative feedback that we exploit to improve sample efficiency. Our design integrates an SGLang-based inference server with an asynchronous training server, enabling hot-swapped speculator updates without service interruption. Crucially, Aurora supports day-0 deployment: a speculator can be served immediately and rapidly adapted to live traffic, improving system performance while providing immediate utility feedback. Across experiments, Aurora achieves a 1.5x day-0 speedup on recently released frontier models (e.g., MiniMax M2.1 229B and Qwen3-Coder-Next 80B). Aurora also adapts effectively to distribution shifts in user traffic, delivering an additional 1.25x speedup over a well-trained but static speculator on widely used models (e.g., Qwen3 and Llama3).

AI.tldr: Aurora is a unified training-serving system that continuously learns speculative decoding speculators from live inference traces, enabling immediate deployment and adaptation to overcome limitations of traditional offline speculator training.
AI.motivation: Traditional speculative decoding deployments separate speculator training from serving, causing three major problems: high time-to-serve (long offline training), delayed utility feedback (true speedup only known after training), and domain-drift degradation (speculators become stale when models are repurposed).
AI.method: Aurora reframes online speculator learning as an asynchronous reinforcement learning problem, using accepted tokens as positive feedback and rejected proposals as implicit negative feedback. It integrates an SGLang-based inference server with an asynchronous training server, enabling hot-swapped speculator updates without service interruption.
AI.result: Aurora achieves 1.5x day-0 speedup on frontier models (MiniMax M2.1 229B and Qwen3-Coder-Next 80B) and adapts effectively to distribution shifts, delivering additional 1.25x speedup over static speculators on widely used models (Qwen3 and Llama3).
AI.conclusion: Aurora's unified training-serving approach enables immediate deployment and continuous adaptation of speculative decoding speculators, overcoming the deployment lag and adaptation issues of traditional offline training methods while providing significant inference speedups.

title: From Core to Detail: Unsupervised Disentanglement with Entropy-Ordered Flows
summary: Learning unsupervised representations that are both semantically meaningful and stable across runs remains a central challenge in modern representation learning. We introduce entropy-ordered flows (EOFlows), a normalizing-flow framework that orders latent dimensions by their explained entropy, analogously to PCA's explained variance. This ordering enables adaptive injective flows: after training, one may retain only the top C latent variables to form a compact core representation while the remaining variables capture fine-grained detail and noise, with C chosen flexibly at inference time rather than fixed during training. EOFlows build on insights from Independent Mechanism Analysis, Principal Component Flows and Manifold Entropic Metrics. We combine likelihood-based training with local Jacobian regularization and noise augmentation into a method that scales well to high-dimensional data such as images. Experiments on the CelebA dataset show that our method uncovers a rich set of semantically interpretable features, allowing for high compression and strong denoising.

AI.tldr: EOFlows is a normalizing-flow framework that orders latent dimensions by explained entropy, enabling adaptive compression and denoising by selecting top C dimensions at inference time.
AI.motivation: Learning unsupervised representations that are both semantically meaningful and stable across runs remains challenging. Current methods lack the ability to flexibly choose representation size after training.
AI.method: Entropy-ordered flows (EOFlows) order latent dimensions by explained entropy (like PCA's explained variance). Combines likelihood-based training with local Jacobian regularization and noise augmentation. Enables adaptive injective flows where only top C latent variables form core representation.
AI.result: Experiments on CelebA show the method uncovers semantically interpretable features, allows for high compression and strong denoising. Scales well to high-dimensional image data.
AI.conclusion: EOFlows provide a flexible framework for unsupervised representation learning with ordered latent dimensions, enabling adaptive compression and noise separation while maintaining semantic interpretability.

title: Improving Credit Card Fraud Detection with an Optimized Explainable Boosting Machine
summary: Addressing class imbalance is a central challenge in credit card fraud detection, as it directly impacts predictive reliability in real-world financial systems. To overcome this, the study proposes an enhanced workflow based on the Explainable Boosting Machine (EBM)-a transparent, state-of-the-art implementation of the GA2M algorithm-optimized through systematic hyperparameter tuning, feature selection, and preprocessing refinement. Rather than relying on conventional sampling techniques that may introduce bias or cause information loss, the optimized EBM achieves an effective balance between accuracy and interpretability, enabling precise detection of fraudulent transactions while providing actionable insights into feature importance and interaction effects. Furthermore, the Taguchi method is employed to optimize both the sequence of data scalers and model hyperparameters, ensuring robust, reproducible, and systematically validated performance improvements. Experimental evaluation on benchmark credit card data yields an ROC-AUC of 0.983, surpassing prior EBM baselines (0.975) and outperforming Logistic Regression, Random Forest, XGBoost, and Decision Tree models. These results highlight the potential of interpretable machine learning and data-driven optimization for advancing trustworthy fraud analytics in financial systems.

AI.tldr: Enhanced EBM workflow with systematic optimization outperforms traditional models in credit card fraud detection while maintaining interpretability.
AI.motivation: Address class imbalance in credit card fraud detection to improve predictive reliability in real-world financial systems, moving beyond conventional sampling techniques that may introduce bias or information loss.
AI.method: Proposes an enhanced workflow based on Explainable Boosting Machine (EBM) optimized through systematic hyperparameter tuning, feature selection, preprocessing refinement, and Taguchi method for optimizing data scaler sequences and model hyperparameters.
AI.result: Achieves ROC-AUC of 0.983, surpassing prior EBM baselines (0.975) and outperforming Logistic Regression, Random Forest, XGBoost, and Decision Tree models on benchmark credit card data.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates the potential of interpretable machine learning and data-driven optimization for advancing trustworthy fraud analytics in financial systems, achieving effective balance between accuracy and interpretability.
